Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: You will now find the comments on your submissions. The final submission is due on 21 July. In case you are running into problems with your assignments and have questions, I will be ultimately available next Wednesday during the usual class hours from 10:15 to 11:45. This will be your last chance to get any advice from, as I will be out of the office and not available the next days. Some general remark: I asked you to submit a report of approx. 10 pages. In the second round I already saw some reports that had near to 20 pages (which is obviously too much), and also some with only 4 pages (which hints that you were a bit too brief). If this concerns you, please make an effort to compress or expand accordingly (and PLEASE NOT by changing the font size or similar).

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: As we had a server downtime today, some of you might not have been able to complete the assignments in time. Please note that you will able to submit up to three days later (i.e. until late Wednesday) without any problems.

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: This important for all of you who do the hifi listening scenario assignment. I just realized that depending on the size of your room, f_max might lead to a FEM with too many degrees of freedom to solve it with the Actran teaching license we use. Please check the number of nodes and adapt the element size and f_max to a value that you do not have more than approx. 15000 nodes. Unfortunately there is no reliable information about the maximum model size that is accepted by our license. However, if there are too many nodes or elements, an meaningful error message will appear.

Messages.Content: There is a new folder with the .edat-files from the examples you can use to compare with.

Discussions.Discussion_Name: If your compute server account is locked ...

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: ... because you did not change your password in time, please write to Bernd Konnerth  <b.konnerth@tu-berlin.de> and ask him to unlock the account and set a new password. Please absolutely remember to use your TUB account, not some other personal Email for this, as we will send out sensitive account information to arbitrary E-mail addresses.

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: Please have a look at the available assignments and take part in the fair choice activity to determine who is working on which topic. If you miss this activity, you will get whatever assignment is available afterward (on request). Important: if you participate, this will count as registration for the exam.

Messages.Content: Hi, has somebody else connection problems with the remote server?

Messages.Author: Felix Bˆckstiegel
Messages.Content: Hi, I am getting a fatal error when trying to run the transmission line simulation with infinite elements. It says "Value mean_density for infinite acoustic 2 can not be automatically set, as no suitable neighbors were found. Note that suitable neighbors are acoustic components sharing the same material as infinite acoustic 2". Both the fluid inside the cabinet, as well as in the region in front of membrane and TL-opening are made of the same material (air). I am getting no other errors, so I have no idea how to proceed. The Actran documentation is scarse and did not help me so far. Does any one here have the same problem or an idea how to solve this? Best regards Felix

Messages.Author: Felix Bˆckstiegel
Messages.Content: Okay it works now! Sorry but I don't really know why...

Messages.Author: Paula Charlotte Ahrens
Messages.Content: Hello, I've been getting this error in Actran whenever I tried to do a quick run: "The element of type EDGE with interpolation order LINEAR is not supported for the component acoustic 1 when performing 3D computations." Does that mean I have created an element in Gmsh that is stopping Actran from doing the analysis? I could't find any element in my skript but I'm also not sure what I should be looking for exactly. Does anyone have an idea? Thanks in advance!

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: This error means that the component "acoustic 1" contains elements that are not 3d, but only 1d. I suspect that when creating the mesh, you somehow marked the edges of the volume to be exported as physical groups or part thereof. You can try to verify this by checking which kind of elements are contained within the respective mesh part.

Messages.Author: Caspar Valentin Zell
Messages.Content: Hi, i ran into some trouble with the Actran licensing, while using a quadratic elements for the annular duct project. I used a mesh with max element size = 85 mm (according to the rule of thumb). This lead to a licensing error. When reinterpolating to linear elements, the license worked and i got the expected results. However at high frequencies the results are not really smooth and most likely inaccurate. Does anyone have the same problem or a solution for this? Thanks! Regards Valentin!

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Gmsh creates Curves at the Top of Semi Spheres

Messages.Author: Sebastian Andre Gnirﬂ
Messages.Content: I have created the Volume in Gmsh by Rotating a Plane surface. Somehow The Curved Surfaces with the Label "Unknown 14" and "Unknown 16" are created.  Is it advisable to delete the curves with recursive delete before meshing?  // Gmsh project created on Tue Jun 18 20:27:37 2024 SetFactory("OpenCASCADE"); //+ Point(1) = {0, 300, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(2) = {-88, 300, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(3) = {-800, 300, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(4) = {-88, 0, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(5) = {-150.5, 62.5, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(6) = {0, 0, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(7) = {-800, 62.5, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(9) = {0, 600, 0, 55.0}; //+ Point(10) = {600, 0, 0, 55.0}; //+ Line(1) = {1, 9}; //+ Line(2) = {1, 2}; //+ Line(3) = {2, 3}; //+ Line(4) = {3, 7}; //+ Line(5) = {7, 5}; //+ Point(8) = {-150.5, 0, 0, 55.0}; //+ Circle(6) = {5, 8, 4}; //+ Circle(7) = {9, 6, 10}; //+ Line(8) = {4, 10}; //+ Curve Loop(1) = {2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, -7, -1}; //+ Plane Surface(1) = {1}; //+ Extrude {{1, 0, 0}, {0, 0, 0}, 2*Pi} {   Surface{1}; } //+ Recursive Delete {   Curve{16}; } //+ Recursive Delete {   Curve{14}; }

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: These lines do no harm except that some of the elements will get aligned along these lines. I would not recommend to delete them because they are needed to define the shape of both of the domes. You may compare to the case of silencer where similar lines are present in both approaches and did no harm when meshing the model.

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Problems with the Dimensions for the Annular Duct

Messages.Author: Sebastian Andre Gnirﬂ
Messages.Content: The given values for the annular duct are not compatible with "stud21" if the inner duct shall be closed off by a curvature smaller than a hemisphere. Can I change the radius (R) from 50mm to 100mm?

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: I am sorry for this. Parametrization of the assignments went wrong. Yes, you will have to use 62.5 mm (not 100 mm because this will give an extra edge between cap and cylinder).

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: In today's class I was demonstrating the harmonic analysis (direct frequency response) for the ski cabin and I could not get the map results visualization to work. I seems like there is a (new?) bug that prevents the results from being stored if the standard (slow) solver is used. The workaround is to use the faster and more efficient 'Krylov' solver (which is to be preferred anyway). You can enable the solver by: right click on 'direct frequency response' (head of tree)  - > add solver -> Krylov right on KRYLOV (at the bottom of tree) and choose 'mumps sub-solver' The effect of this that the results get stored correctly AND the solution is faster. See the screenshot for clarification.

Messages.Author: Paul Rudi Vincenzo Testa
Messages.Content: The sketch in the assignment seems to indicate, that H,B, and T are the external dimensions of the enclosure. But in the parameters24 sheet they are named as interior dimensions. Which should we use?

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: The sketch is just a sketch and is rather vague about the kind of dimensions. That's why the dimensions are explicitly named 'interior'. Together with the wall thickness (where applicable), you will get the outer dimensions when needed.

Messages.Author: Felix Bˆckstiegel
Messages.Content: Good evening, I am not fully clear on the assignment definition for 2.6 (TL). It says "Also, show the vertical directivity at the height of the center of the diaphragm at the dominant resonant frequencies". Does this mean apart from the reference point 1m in front of the speaker (on-axis), we should run the calculation for a second point, at 1m distance as well, but rotated 90∞ upwards, so a point +1m in z-direction from the diaphragm center? And at the resonant frequencies means NOT the full frequency response like on the frontal point? If so, what else is asked for by this? Kind regards Felix

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: The directivity would include the angle-dependent radiation from the loudspeaker. 'Vertical' means that not the full solid angle is to be considered, but just the vertical angle (spanning which range ? - you may come to the conclusion that 180∞ would be a good choice to draw a directivity diagram). This should be done at just the resonant frequencies (or if that remains to vague, you will have to select at least one frequency you think is a characteristic one for the problem. Hope this helps.

Messages.Author: Felix Bˆckstiegel
Messages.Content: Thank you for the explanation. So our rotational axis is trough the center of the diaphragm I'd assume? And then we calculate +/- 90∞ vertical (starting at 0∞ on-axis) in say 5∞ steps at 1m distance as well? This would be 31 additional "imission points" for which we run the FEM simulation but just for a few resonant frequencies instead of the whole bandwidth, is this right?

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: Yes, this would be one possible way to do it. The distance 1 m is not given, tough. You would have to decide by yourself.

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Dimensions for the bass reflex loudspeaker are not correct

Messages.Author: Paul Simon
Messages.Content: Hello,  I have just noticed when creating a CAD model for the loudspeaker that the height of the diaphragm center and the radius of the diaphragm exceed the interior height of the loudspeaker for stud20. Is there a way to correct the dimensions? Best regards  Paul

Messages.Author: Ennes Sarradj
Messages.Content: Oops, how did that happen? I will look into this. Probably there is something wrong with the parameters. To get rid of the problem please use H=0.600 instead.

Messages.Author: Paul Simon
Messages.Content: Okay, thank you.
